title: Navigating the tightrope of teen fatherhood; when the birds and bees talk gets real. (Ep 257)
caption: false

channel_info.title: Robbie Kramer
channel_info.description:
I'm Robbie Kramer 🎙Host of The Inner Confidence Podcast & Founder of Inner Confidence, Inc.

I lived an exhilarating single life filled with adventures and lessons, and ultimately achieved what I had always aspired to – finding an amazing, feminine, and loving wife. 

I believe my experiences provide a rare balance of wild freedom and committed love, equipping me with the insights to help you navigate the complexities of dating and relationships in today's world. Let me guide you to embrace your desires, improve your social prowess, and ultimately attract the partner who aligns with your highest aspirations.

You won’t find any fluffy, new-age, or cringy stuff here, just tested, proven and actionable advice that yields results.

Apply to join our exclusive Inner Confidence Community of ambitious men who are actively working together to achieve their goals faster   ► https://innerconfidence.com/community

You can email me at robbie@innerconfidence.com with any questions or comments.

transcription: {"text": "One thing that I feel like my dad really burned into my brain was like, whatever you do, don't get a girl pregnant at a young age, right? Like when he had to talk with me or whatever, he was like condoms. That's like all I remember from like the birds and the bees. I was just like, wear condoms, condoms, condoms, right? I say it all the time to my son, too. So that's how hardcore are you guys about that? Yeah, you know, because they could easily be like, well, look, mom and dad are a great model, like our family's dope. So they're like, hey, maybe that's the path. If they came to me and they found themselves pregnant, I would, of course, support. But you want to put as much friction on this topic as possible, I feel with your kids, because it is just completely transformative in its capacity to completely change their life, right? Yeah. You're now responsible for someone else attached to another person for the rest of your life. It's not to be taken lightly. So putting friction points and resistance on if that ever came up in conversation as if this is something that they wanted to entertain or do or enter into early, you could say, I would certainly like, you know, not shut it down, but I would put some resistance on that decision for them. Got it. But support them ultimately. Right.
